Expectation1: Enforcing the law and maintaining public order
Situation1: A public protest begins to escalate, with tension rising between opposing groups
Situation2: They have been scheduled to chant a portion during the service.
Story: The radio crackled as I stood at the edge of the protest, my badge heavy on my chest. The crowd’s shouts grew louder, and I could see tempers flaring between the two groups. As a police officer, I was expected to stay, to keep the peace, to be the calm in the chaos. But my phone buzzed in my pocket—a reminder that tonight was my turn to chant the Torah portion at synagogue. It wasn’t just any service; it was the anniversary of my grandfather’s passing, and my family would be waiting, expecting me to honor our tradition. I felt the weight of my uniform and my yarmulke, tucked away in my bag. The city needed me here, but my community and my family needed me there. My heart pounded as I watched the protest swell, torn between duty to the law and devotion to my faith, knowing I couldn’t be in both places at once.
